Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Myxobacteria rely on cell-cell signaling and gliding motility to live as multicellular organisms that build fruiting body structures in response to starvation. How cell-cell signaling organizes these developmental processes remains a fundamental biological question. To help understand these processes Myxococcus xanthus gliding motility mutants were isolated. A characteristic of the mutants is that they are rescued by extracellular complementation (stimulation) from cells that contain the corresponding wild type gene. Two of these known mutants encode lipoproteins and the mechanism for stimulation involves efficient cell-to-cell transfer of the cognate lipoprotein. Transfer does not involve extracellular secretion, but instead requires physical contact between donor and recipient cells. One of these lipoproteins, Tgl, is polarly localized and when transferred to a recipient cell activates the assembly of the type IV pili gliding motility motor. Specifically, Tgl transfer regulates the assembly of the outer membrane PilQ secretin channel for pilus transport. In general, lipoprotein transfer represents a novel form of cell-cell interactions that may play a role in coordinating cellular movements, forming biofilms and/or the recognition of different cell types. This project will use molecular genetic and fluorescent video microscopy methods to understand the mechanism and broader biological significance of lipoprotein transfer in bacteria.

Broader Impacts
This project involves the education and training of undergraduate and graduate students in an EPSCoR state. Elements of this project will be incorporated into undergraduate microbial genetic lecture and laboratory classes illustrating current research methods and approaches to students. Graduate students will be trained in scientific thinking and in molecular genetic techniques. An outreach component involves introducing and training Native Americans in microbial genetics. This outreach effort includes trips to a tribal college to recruit Native American students to conduct a summer research internship at the University of Wyoming. Student training in the lab is an interactive process between individuals at all levels. This work will generate high quality research papers and students supported by the project will present at national scientific meetings. Society at large will benefit from the training of young scientists. In addition, the project will provide a broader understanding of how cells interact in communities such as biofilms or in primitive developmental tissues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual goal of this project was to understand how myxobacteria transfer lipoproteins between cells. Several key findings were made toward this goal and we also developed an understanding for how myxobacteria recognize each other. First, by constructing heterologous protein reporter fusions it was found that simply a type II signal sequence for outer membrane (OM) lipoprotein localization was sufficient to allow heterologous protein transfer between cells. Second, by use of lipophilic fluorescent dyes, membrane lipids were also shown to be transferred between cells, suggesting the mechanism of transfer involves OM fusion between cells. Third, we identified two proteins, TraA and TraB, that are required in both recipient and donor cells for OM protein and lipid transfer. However, unlike known transport systems, the TraAB system works in a mutualistic manner in that OM material is exchanged bidirectionally. Fourth, OM exchange was found to be selective and involves cell-cell recognition among environmental isolates. TraA is the molecular specificity determinant and functions as a cell surface homophilic receptor. Moreover, the TraA receptor is polymorphic and those polymorphisms determine recognition specificity among strains. Thus simply swapping traA alleles allowed strains to recognize different partners for OM exchange. Fifth, OM exchange was found to regulate social interactions among myxobacteria including their ability to swarm and develop fruiting bodies. In addition, protection from bacteriocin-like killing between stains was conferred by a traA allele specific mechanism. In a broader context these finding have implications for how myxobacteria recognize kin cells in their environment and can transition from free-living cells into multicellular fruiting bodies. In evolutionary terms traA functions as a rare greenbeard gene that recognizes others bearing the same allele to confer beneficial treatment. We further suggest that TraA helps guide the transition of single cells into a cooperative tissue-like bacterial community.

The broader impacts of this project included training a postdoctoral fellow,
several graduate students and undergraduate students in our laboratory. Elements of this research project were used as the basis of a Bacterial Genetics laboratory pod (MOLB 4250) taught by the PI in the spring semesters of 2012 and 2013. Outreach efforts also resulted in two high school students working in the laboratory, microbiology demonstrations being conducted in three local elementary classes, and a Native American student being recruited, trained and paid to work in the lab.
